importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the latest news update regarding the U.S. Department of Justice's foreign bribery indictment against Smartmatic, indicating the most current development in this politically charged legal case.
The year when the alleged bribery occurred in the Philippines, relating to the procurement of election technology contracts for the country's 2016 elections.
The year when Smartmatic filed defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures and media outlets alleging false claims about vote manipulation in the 2020 U.S. election.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Smartmatic has been actively litigating defamation claims against pro-Trump figures and media entities, with the recent indictment adding a layer of credibility and reputational challenge to those claims.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. Justice Department has indicted Smartmatic, a voting technology company, on foreign bribery charges related to a $1 million bribe allegedly paid to a top Philippine election official in 2016 to secure election contracts.
The indictment does not allege voter fraud or election rigging in the U.S. or elsewhere, only foreign bribery and money laundering.

The charges could severely undermine Smartmatic's claims in ongoing defamation lawsuits against Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, Rudy Giuliani, and Mike Lindell, by suggesting its reputation is damaged by criminal conduct, not just false claims of election fraud.
Smartmatic denies wrongdoing, claims political bias and influence in the investigation, and asserts it has cooperated with authorities.
Los Angeles County maintains that its contract with Smartmatic is valid and protected, and that the indictment has no bearing on the integrity of its voting systems.

Pro-Trump figures and media outlets have used the indictment to challenge Smartmatic's claims of reputational harm, arguing that the company's criminal behavior undermines its standing as a victim of defamation.

Legal experts say the indictment makes it difficult for Smartmatic to prove that its damages stem solely from defamatory statements about the 2020 election, potentially weakening its damages claims in court.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Justice Department has filed foreign bribery charges against Smartmatic, a voting technology company, alleging a $1 million bribe was paid to a top Philippine election official in 2016 to secure contracts for that country's 2016 elections. The indictment does not involve any claims of voter fraud or election rigging in the U.S. Smartmatic denies all wrongdoing, claiming political bias and influence in the investigation. The case has major implications for Smartmatic’s ongoing defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures including Fox News host Jeanine Pirro, former Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani, and MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell, who have long claimed Smartmatic's systems flipped votes in 2020. The bribery allegations now provide a potential counter-narrative to Smartmatic’s claim that its reputation has been damaged solely by these false statements, undermining its ability to assert that the defamation alone caused its reputational harm. Legal experts say this could severely weaken Smartmatic's damages claims in court and influence settlement negotiations. Los Angeles County has stated that the indictment has no bearing on the integrity of its election systems or contracts with Smartmatic.
title: Smartmatic Indicted in Foreign Bribery Case, Possibly Endangering Its Lawsuits Against Fox News and Giuliani
